1.11.1.title: Overview
1.11.1.content:
Management of Change (MOC) ensures that changes to plans, procedures, equipment, or personnel are properly assessed and managed.

**Why MOC Matters for Well Control:**
- Changes can introduce unforeseen risks
- Original risk assessments may no longer apply
- Barriers may be affected by changes
- Personnel may not be aware of changes
- Procedures may need updating

All changes with potential well control implications shall go through MOC process.

1.11.2.title: Types of Changes
1.11.2.content:
Changes requiring MOC assessment include:

**Operational Changes:**
- Deviation from drilling program
- Mud weight changes outside planned window
- Change in casing setting depth
- Change in BOP configuration
- Addition of special operations (MPD, UBD)

**Equipment Changes:**
- BOP component substitution
- Choke or manifold changes
- Pit monitoring system changes
- Control system modifications
- Wellhead equipment changes

**Personnel Changes:**
- Key position changes during critical operations
- Changes in supervision structure
- Contractor changes

**Procedural Changes:**
- Modifications to standard procedures
- Bridging document updates
- Emergency response changes

**Note:** Routine operational decisions within the drilling program (e.g., mud weight adjustments within planned range) do not require formal MOC.

1.11.3.title: MOC Process
1.11.3.content:
The MOC process follows these steps:

**1. Identify the Change**
- Clearly describe what is changing
- Identify what was originally planned
- Determine the reason for change

**2. Assess the Change**
- What are the well control implications?
- Are barriers affected?
- What new risks are introduced?
- What additional mitigations are needed?
- Are procedures adequate?
- Is competency adequate?

**3. Approve the Change**
- Appropriate authority level approval
- Higher risk changes require higher approval
- Document the approval

**4. Implement the Change**
- Update relevant documentation
- Communicate to affected personnel
- Implement mitigations before proceeding
- Verify understanding

**5. Monitor and Review**
- Verify change is working as planned
- Watch for unintended consequences
- Post-implementation review

1.11.4.title: Approval Authority
1.11.4.content:
Changes require approval at appropriate levels:

**Drilling Supervisor Level:**
- Minor operational deviations
- Routine adjustments within program parameters
- Personnel changes within shift

**OIM/Operations Manager Level:**
- Significant operational changes
- Equipment substitutions
- Key personnel changes
- Procedure modifications

**Senior Management Level:**
- Major changes to well design
- BOP configuration changes
- Special operations addition (HPHT, MPD)
- Changes with significant risk implications

**Emergency Changes:**
- Safety-critical changes may be implemented immediately
- Retrospective MOC documentation required
- Post-implementation review mandatory

1.11.5.title: Communication of Changes
1.11.5.content:
All changes must be effectively communicated:

**Who to Inform:**
- All personnel affected by the change
- Shore-based support team
- Regulatory authorities where required
- Service companies if their scope affected

**How to Communicate:**
- Toolbox talks for operational changes
- Updated documentation distributed
- Shift handovers must include changes
- Posting of significant changes

**Verification:**
- Confirm receipt and understanding
- Ask questions to verify comprehension
- Document that communication occurred

1.11.6.title: MOC Documentation
1.11.6.content:
MOC shall be documented using the standard form:

**Documentation Includes:**
- Description of original plan/equipment/procedure
- Description of proposed change
- Reason for change
- Risk assessment
- Mitigations identified
- Approval signatures
- Communication record
- Post-implementation review

**Record Retention:**
- MOC records retained with well records
- Available for audit
- Referenced in daily reports

**Template:** See Appendix B for MOC Form

1.11.7.title: Temporary vs Permanent Changes
1.11.7.content:
Changes may be temporary or permanent:

**Temporary Changes:**
- Have defined end date or condition
- Reversal plan documented
- Regular review of continued need
- Same MOC process applies
- Example: Temporary equipment substitution while repair is made

**Permanent Changes:**
- Incorporate into standard documentation
- Training updated if needed
- Procedures revised
- Example: Updated kill procedure based on lessons learned

**Caution:** Temporary changes that persist become normalized. Review all temporary changes regularly and either make permanent (with full documentation) or revert.
